docs.title: Welcome
docs.text:
This documentation site is generated from the docs/ directory of the project repository. Navigate using the menu above or use the search bar to find what you need.

For the full project README and template usage instructions, refer to the repository root.

This document provides a lightweight log of technical and product decisions made throughout the project. It is intended for teams that do not adopt formal ADRs but still want to maintain a traceable record of significant choices. If your project uses ADRs, refer to the ADR index instead.

When to add an entry: - A decision that affects how a feature is built or how the system is structured - A choice between two or more meaningful alternatives - A trade-off that future team members would need context to understand - Any decision that was deliberately made and is not self-evident from the code

Format: Keep entries short and factual. Focus on context and reasoning, not implementation details.

docs.title: What is an ADR?
docs.text:
An Architecture Decision Record is a document that captures an important architectural decision made during the course of a project, together with its context, the alternatives considered, and the reasoning behind the final choice.

ADRs are not just about documenting what was decided — they are about documenting why. This makes it possible for anyone joining the project later to understand the rationale behind the current state of the system, without having to reconstruct decisions from memory or scattered conversations.

docs.title: When to Write an ADR
docs.text:
Write an ADR whenever a decision:

  • Has a significant impact on the architecture, structure, or behavior of the system
  • Is difficult or costly to reverse
  • Involves trade-offs between meaningful alternatives
  • Would be hard for a new team member to understand without context

When in doubt, write it. A short ADR is better than no ADR.

docs.title: ADR Lifecycle
docs.text:
Each ADR has a status that reflects its current state:

Status Description Proposed The decision is under discussion and has not been formally accepted yet Accepted The decision has been agreed upon and is in effect Deprecated The decision was once accepted but is no longer relevant or recommended Superseded The decision has been replaced by a newer ADR

docs.title: How to Create a New ADR
docs.text:
1. Copy the file 001-template.md and rename it following the pattern: NNN-short-title-in-kebab-case.md, where NNN is the next sequential number.
  2. Fill in all sections of the template.
  3. Set the status to Proposed until the decision is agreed upon by the relevant stakeholders.
  4. Update the index table below when the ADR is accepted.
  5. If a decision is later superseded, update its status and add a reference to the new ADR.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
This directory contains all architectural and domain diagrams for this project. Diagrams are written using Mermaid, which renders natively in GitHub without any external tools or image files.

To preview diagrams locally, use a Mermaid-compatible editor such as the Mermaid Live Editor at mermaid.live, or install a Mermaid extension for your code editor.

docs.title: How to Write a Mermaid Diagram
docs.text:
Diagrams are embedded in Markdown files using fenced code blocks with the mermaid language identifier:

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Start] --> B[End]
```

docs.title: Diagram Index
docs.text: File Type Description c4-context.md C4 Level 1 — Context The system in its environment and its external actors c4-container.md C4 Level 2 — Container The internal building blocks of the system c4-component.md C4 Level 3 — Component The internal components of a specific container deployment.md Deployment Infrastructure topology and how containers map to infrastructure er-diagram.md Entity-Relationship Data model and relationships between entities sequence-flows.md Sequence Communication flows between components for critical operations state-diagram.md State Lifecycle and state transitions of key domain entities

docs.title: Diagramming Guidelines
docs.text:
• Keep diagrams focused. One diagram should communicate one idea clearly.
  • Prefer accuracy over completeness. A diagram that is partially wrong is worse than no diagram.
  • Update diagrams whenever the system changes. An outdated diagram is misleading.
  • Add a brief description above each diagram explaining its purpose and what the reader should take away from it.
  • Use consistent naming between diagrams and the rest of the documentation.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
The Component diagram zooms into a single Container (defined in the C4 Container diagram) and shows its internal building blocks — components, modules, or services — and how they communicate with each other. This diagram answers the question: "What is inside this container and how is it structured?" It is most valuable for complex containers where the internal structure is non-obvious or actively evolving.

See also: C4 Context Diagram | C4 Container Diagram

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: State diagrams show the lifecycle of a domain entity — the states it can be in and the events or conditions that cause it to transition from one state to another. They are most useful for entities whose behavior changes significantly depending on their current state. Each diagram in this file should focus on a single entity.
